awd_titl_txt: Idaho Making Progress Against Critical Teacher Shortages
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national need for preparing and retaining highly qualified secondary science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) teachers, particularly in rural areas. Centered in southeastern Idaho, this project will assess student perceptions and perceived barriers to STEM education careers. The project will also work to develop a research-based, efficient, and affordable pathway for potential STEM educators to become and continue as effective K-12 teachers in high-need schools. Roughly 25% of Idaho’s revenue comes from science and technology. Investing in STEM education and building a local workforce has clear economic implications for the state. Through the use of data, the team will develop more effective approaches to STEM teaching and improve recruitment and retention of STEM education students with the ultimate goal of improving STEM instruction in schools throughout the region.

This project at Idaho State University (ISU) includes partnerships with the College of Southern Idaho, as well as Pocatello, American Falls, and Shoshone-Bannock School Districts. Project goals include determining local school district needs in recruiting, retaining, and supporting secondary STEM teachers through data collection and analysis, focusing on underserved rural populations including Hispanic and Native American populations. This information will shed light on possible causes of and influences on the STEM educator shortage. Results from this project will lay the foundation for a Track 1: Scholarships and Stipends proposal that will streamline and modernize ISU STEM education programs and positively impact the quantity of available high-quality STEM educators in Idaho and the region. Southeastern Idaho and the Intermountain West regions are unique in diversity and geography but the lessons learned from this project could be extrapolated to other rural areas, including those with higher Native American and Hispanic populations and those impacted by elevated poverty. This Capacity Building project is supported through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce). The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 STEM teachers and experienced, exemplary K-12 teachers to become STEM master teachers in high-need school districts. It also supports research on the retention and effectiveness of K-12 STEM teachers in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Idaho State University sought to determine local rural school districts’ immediate and long-term needs in recruiting, retaining, and supporting secondary STEM teachers, focusing on underserved rural school districts, including the Hispanic and Native American populations. ISU intend to address shortages by addressing student perceptions and perceived barriers to STEM education careers.

 The project resulted in substantive data regarding student perceptions about the profession but also about the paths to become a STEM teacher. With these data, ISU is better able to generate accurate understanding of the field of education and encourage students to succeed as education students and professional educators. We have used the data to make recommendations about ISU programming and ways to streamline our program to increase the number of STEM education graduates. These recommendations include:

  • Train and inform STEM faculty members with advising materials specific to K-12 STEM teaching
  • Ensure each College of Science and Engineering department encourages teaching as a career to those declaring majors/minors in their department
  • Include open K-12 STEM teaching positions in announcements to College of Science and Engineering students on job opportunities and internships
  • Offer undergraduate STEM education research experiences to STEM students to increase interest in K-12 STEM teaching
  • Create a liaison position between the College of Education and College of Science and Engineering to facilitate communication, support recruitment and retention of STEM students interested in teaching, align STEM and educational courses to programmatic outcomes
  • Create pathways for more experiential STEM teaching opportunities in high schools so potential STEM teachers can better understand the nature of STEM teaching careers
  • Create a mentorship program for STEM education graduates to further develop pedagogical and content expertise and maintain connections/relationships with ISU.

In doing so, we now understand potential and actual barriers with respect to recruiting and retaining STEM teachers that are specifically related to our region and institution.

Furthermore, the College of Education’s Masters of Arts in Teaching program, which is a graduate level certification process for those who hold a degree in a field other than education, continues to grow and remains a strong and viable pathway for recruiting teachers who already hold a STEM degree. This pathway also offers incentives not found through other non-traditional and alternate certification routes as increased pay comes from a master’s degree in Idaho. Likewise, faculty in STEM disciplines now understand the advantages of leveraging this program to develop STEM teachers. These conversations, and their future implications,  were perhaps one of the more significant outcomes of the project.

Additionally, interview data indicate mathematics teachers continue to be a major area of need for local principals, followed by chemistry and biology teachers. Based on these findings, ISU has hired two additional mathematics education faculty to start next year, one within the mathematics department and one within the college of education, to develop stronger collaborations between the educational and STEM content disciplines and to better align programmatic outcomes in mathematics education; such collaborations already exist between biology and biology education faculty. Principals also indicated they wanted aa stronger mentorship between ISU faculty and newly hired STEM teachers. As such, the ISU College of Education is currently developing such a program to meet these needs.
